abstracts.cdata!:
The Congo Health Sector Services
            Development Project received a moderately satisfactory
            outcome with moderate risk to development. Both the Bank and
            the Borrower received moderately satisfactory ratings for
            their performances. Component 1 was found to be too
            ambitious with little design built in. Thus, the objective
            of the component was changed from Strengthening leadership
            capacities of Ministry of Health, Social Services and Family
            Welfare (MSASF) in managing a functioning and decentralized
            health system to Access to a package of high priority
            health services aimed at addressing the three health
            problems that account for the largest share of the burden of
            disease in the Congo: malaria, maternal and child mortality,
            and interrupting the transmission of mother to child of the
            HIV virus. Component 3 would become Component 2 to provide
            support to new Component 1 and include rehabilitating and
            equipping of primary health care covered by performance
            based financing, and safe disposal of biomedical waste in
            these facilities. Activities under Component 4 were narrowed
            and put under the new Component 1 and delivered through a
            performance based financing pilot. Five lessons were learned
            from this project and are as follows: (1) A preliminary
            political economy assessment may help identify appropriate
            institutional frameworks for project coordination. (2) For
            large-scale, complex projects a dedicated team of
            professionals must be created for effective implementation.
            (3) Streamline resources to the beneficiaries. In situations
            where leadership and coordination remain weak at the central
            level, efficient and effective interventions that streamline
            resources to the decentralized level where services are
            provided to the target population should be introduced. (4)
            Reliance on significant counterpart and development partner
            financing can impede achieving project results. (5)
            Reinforce Monitoring and Evaluation systems through a
            two-pronged approach can have significant effect.
